at least we dont accept ssl3 (SSLv3: No supported ciphers found) \o/
heehee: openssl s_client -connect www.chromium.org:443 </dev/null 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -text -noout | grep 'Signature Algorithm'

"Today, SHA-1 is at the point where a collision attack is estimated to take 261 work and a chosen-prefix collision to take 277. Both are below the design strength of 280 and even that design strength isn't great by today's standards."
https://www.imperialviolet.org/2014/05/14/sha256.html
2^61 and 2^77 and 2^80 (copy pasta fail)

omg my irc is highlighting this channel but its not going away when I change buffers
meskarune: thats because #arch-security is always important :D :P
heh
meskarune: we will update the hash next time the cert needs to be replaced
which thanks to people panicing due to heartbleed is around 2 years
really the main reason I made the bug is because chrome is going to flag sites that use sha1, which might deter users
I feel like other browsers might follow suit
meskarune: in which release?
chrome 39 it looks like
http://googleonlinesecurity.blogspot.com/2014/09/gradually-sunsetting-sha-1.html
in chrome 41 it will be marked with a red X
"certificates that expire on or after 1 January 2017, and which include a SHA-1-based signature as part of the certificate chain"
I guess if the cert is expiring before then it might be ok
Chrome 41 (Branch point in Q1 2015)
it expires before
in 39 it will be a yellow warning triangle
04/14/2016 actually
so we get a yellow triangle. big deal
"Sites with end-entity (“leaf”) certificates that expire on or after 1 January 2017" its not even yellow as far as i can read
right those will be red
not in 39, only later
yeah
in 41
we just gotta make sure the next cert uses sha2
well, you could also reissue a cert with sha2 :P
takes like 20 min maybe
unless the arch servers have a complicated setup
and costs money
no, it doesn't
ofc it does
I just got mine reissued and did not have to pay at all
geotrust rapid ssl certs
you can't issue a new cert with startssl if the current one for a domain is active
I doubt they'll let you change the hash
you can totally get a reissued cert
like if your private key was stolen, you can have them reissue a new cert with the same expires date as whatever you ordered
I have never been charged to get a reissued certificate
you don't use startssl
oh damn, startssl charges for reissuing certs?
you can only issue/reissue if you have no active cert for a domain or if the cert expires in 2 weeks. if you have an active cert you have to revoke it
and revoking costs money
startssl is move expensive than other people I"ve bought from :/
are they more secure or something?
$60 for unlimited multidomain, wildcard certs that are valid for 2 years is by no means expensive
and the fee for revoking is because it happens to be rather expensive to run a set of OCSP servers
doesn't take into account that OCSP rarely works, but hey, they have it

idk, I got a rapid ssl cert for a single domain for 4 years that was only $32. Other companies like comodo never charged to reissue certs. I know it costs money of course. I am just surprised that a company would charge to reissue a cert when there is known security issue that isn't even the customer's fault. :/
heartbleed or sha1 or whatever else comes up in the future
but go ahead and mark that as won't fix or low priority or give it a due date of Jan 2017 I guess
:P
revoking certs and issuing new ones doesn't even help against most cases so nobody would have had to do that after heartbleed
yeah, I agree about that
i disagree: revoking after heartbleed was important
it has ben proven that rsa private key may get leaked
https://www.imperialviolet.org/2014/04/19/revchecking.html
revoking only helps in one very specific case and that's not one of the common attack cases
ah yeah there i agree
btw extracting private key throught heartbleed is fun :D was even a task in the last CTF
its also not super likely that some organization out the wild will put forth resources to create a fake cert to intercept archlinux.org traffic
makes more sense to do that with banks
or bitcoin
bitcoin websites
unlikly and even in near future only government-like sized powers will be capable of
or universities
oh it's totally possible if someone takes over dns
as is explained in the blog post linked above
anyway, changing the key/cert after heartbleed was unnecessary

s/he/she/
meskarune: sorry
its cool :P

unless they are hiding stuff the rest of us don't know about ;)
oh sure we are
I guess thats why the topic says world domination in #archlinux ;D
apparently it's possible to trick the startssl webui into giving you a new cert if you add another unused domain to the list. no idea if that works for wildcard certs though

grsecurity is basically...

PaX + lots of misc grsec features + grsec RBAC + lots of fixes for stuff upstream doesn't care about + backported fixes
PaX is a lot of nice defenses against memory corruption exploits

for split packages i would name the base package but if ASAs are meant to name binary packages then i would make a separate ASA for each affected package in the split package

yeah, i agree

and... maybe could add a script to check for packages to be updated for security fixes :)
checkasa - list installed packages which have fixes available

ok sent you a test
fsckd: i was kinda thinking of a way to incorporate that into pacman

but an external script would be easier
rgacogne: puh that will be hard, there have been tons of "metadata" discussion regarding pacman defaults
but at the long term maybe that is a good idea
rgacogne: yes, an external tool would do it and if it turns out to be usefull for many people maybe it gets into pacman xD

that would be awesome
checkasa could be done now in a hackish way by pulling info from the mailing list and comparing versions
neat idea :D
yep but later you will need some kind of "database" of flat file archive in ~/.config or something like that. in 1 year you will have to pull millions of ASA's :D
haha indeed
(even if it's not a million, a tool that copies the mailing list (just one month) every time could be unacceptable load)
fsckd: if we have something and if the tracking board in also finished we could also combine that and have a backend that serves the infos (only deltas, local storage would be nice either way)
cool
publishing advisories for wireshark now...
do you create those mails manually btw?
also you just sent one from your private address
Bluewind: half way yes half way no, i'm copying the template from my proof-of-concept tracking-dashboard xD
Bluewind: just candeled that, will republish
I'd suggest using either a script to send them or thunderbird's templates
if you have a draft mail you can not only save it as a draft but also as a template. the template will also save the selected sender
yep brilliant idea, thats what the dashboard is currently doing, adding template with package name, version etc filled out :D
but the desription and impact needs to be done manually anyway
Bluewind: but then i have to fill in package-name etc by hand? never used thunderbird templates, will look into them
it's just like a draft mail but you won't loose the "draft"/template
i see, will check that out, merci
but I think using a script to send the mails is probably better in your case
if i may ask, where will the dashboard run?
I have some perl code that sends gpg signed multipart mails, I can show you the relevant bits
Bluewind: sure i love to read code anyway, would be interested in seeing that
fsckd: not totally sure, currently only prototype. i will have to talk to Dan first... and then start a discussion on ML about that
but I guess I can just show you the whole thing. it's a script that sends billing mails including a pdf and gpg sig https://paste.xinu.at/VHk/
you should be able to rip out most of the stuff
fsckd: i can start that on my own machines but maybe it should get moved into the arch infrastructure... but thats all long term stuff that will get discussed by everyone after i provide a preview :)
Bluewind: thanks, its totally fine
also it uses msmtp to send the mail, I can give you a config for that if you need one
rgacogne: starting to write ASA for drupal
I guess if you have a json representation of an ASA that script should be easy enough to adapt
wow great great idea. thats super sweet thank you, you just extended my vision :D
Bluewind: until now i was planning to only do a draft generator there, but your right, managing that from there give different adventages
you should totally go for json in the webapp
Bluewind: sure i always prefere json over stinky xml :P
and json api's are easy to code against
ACTION just extended his notes and todos
btw if there are multiple CVEs how about putting the CVE specific links near the CVE description?
it's somewhat cumbersome to find a specific link in those long lists

hmm not sure, do you think it would make it more readable? I normally dislike links inbetween rather than at the footer (like references) for me personally i prefere having those clustered rather then inline
my usecase is that I read the mail, notice that most of the linux CVEs are for KVM, except 1 or 2 and I'll want  details on those

just my personal thoughts on that :) But later (if we put ASA sendin into the dashboard) we may have an ASA specific link to the dashboard, showing the ASA mit meta-data replace by links (f.e. CVE ids, package name etc)
I guess that would work yeah
ah okay i see your point
I also noticed you put "- " in front of each CVE description while remi doesn't. nothing major though
I do fine your's easier to read though (mostly because of the linebreak after the id + type)
nah (no blame!) but after his jenkins ASA from Oct i added those to have the same layout :D
Yeah we have some small differences, thats also a good reason to get it generated rather then written
hm asa 201411-11 for flashplugin doesn't have any details. you'll have to expect cases where there are no descriptions but lots of IDs for the same type of issue
your really a man of details that you recognized those (compliment!) i appreciate all feedback and i'm also looking forward that one day its impossible to distinguish the writer on the content :D
the CVE list at the header is also different, no commas and aligned wrapped newlines
will discuss those with rgacogne once he is back
Bluewind: true, flashplugin description section looks "strange", whats your opinion how to do that in a way like with single IDs? replicating text and 1 CVE-ID per block also sounds stupid
I'd list the IDs and if there is no description put the type in the next line
so type instead of the description
as for the header, I don't care too much about that
I mainly want it to be easy to read/skim over the list of descriptions and figure out if I'm affected by the issues
good idea, i will create some previews of such cases later after writing the remaining ASAs
with the kernel I just skipped all the KVM stuff
totally agree on that! :D
we (arch-sec) are still very young and in my opinion we already have nicer advisories then several other distros :P
oh they are awesome
helps a lot if I can just follow that list and be quite sure I don't miss any security updates
lol, i just recognized that the last kernel ASA has another kind of description layout XD
I still follow fd, oss-sec and bugtraq but those are soooo high volume and so many different types of subjects
yep, thats also my plan to (at least) be as good as all other distros (to be honest i want that we are even better :P) in resolving security issues fast and transparent
maybe we can also consider to drop "Arch Linux Security Advisory" from the title
